ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course is invaluable to students looking for real-world experience and working on projects in a professional, group setting. I do think that the newly introduced "memos" were a waste of time, especially for those of us working on projects we had already started in a previous semester. My time could have been spent working on the project my client needed rather than writing a memo.
This course is a great opportunity for students seeking to have a professional experience while at school.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The projects are fantastic!
I really love the project I'm on, and I'm happy that my client is Lisa, who is also our project supervisor. Makes things very easy and goals are clear.
The best part is the autonomy given to students to handle the project and client. Travels are also a plus!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I found the 3 memos to be pretty unhelpful. It felt more like busy work then something that actually helped our group synthesize our work and what still needed to be done. I would recommend either less memos or scraping them entirely. Check-ins with faculty supervisors are more important and a better use of everyone's time
back-and-forth with project advisor limited, advisor did not provide much substantive feedback

Pushing prospective clients to really lock in what they need down and incentivizing them to stay involved throughout the semester. Students have a role to play in this but sometimes we really needed more helpful from faculty.

I really feel that the practice of "logging hours" is a hand-holding exercise. We are all adults here, I don't think we need to be logging our hours every step of the way. If the project advisor or client needs something by a deadline, I will have completed that deliverable by that time. I shouldn't need to log my hours to "prove" I was working on the deliverable for a certain amount of time.
Regular meetings with supervisor. Have the supervisor provide feedback on your our throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Since I took this course for the second time this semester, I wasn't really involved in the class itself.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: amazing in providing opportunities to work with real clients on topics not covered in other classes

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It fulfilled my capstone requirement as an MEM student
To work on a project/topic that I have no other opportunity at FES to pursue
I wanted the experience.
I like the interaction with clients and to work with real life projects applying the knowledge I've gained so far.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to be able to bounce ideas off of my team and to divide the work. I think we all brought different experiences and perspectives to our client project which was helpful in strengthening our final deliverable.
Could have used more coaching at the beginning to help students learn about setting goals, agendas, and giving constructive criticism (kind of like what SOM does during orientation)
I had one other partner working on this project, and she was awesome. Super reliable and always ready for group meetings and deliverables.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Much of what you get out of this course depends on your client and their given project. While less engaged clients with vague project goals can still be a valuable lesson in consulting and project management, it's always better to look back on work that may actually help the client. Unfortunately, it's hard to suss out the good clients and projects at the beginning of the semester.
Definitely take at least one project-based course working with a client, but wait for the right project to come along that you're really interested in.
Schedule weekly meetings with your advisor. Start project work on day 1 to log enough hours.
